page.title: 06The Beacon Hill Kiwi
page.content: On the slope of Beacon Hill above Bulford Camp a Kiwi is cut out of the chalk. It stands 128 metres high by 36 metres wide.A month before the Armistice at the end of the 1st World War, Major Metcalfe, a New Zealander, asked the War Office if his men might cut a Kiwi out of the chalk in the style of the ancient Wiltshire white horses. The Kiwi was drawn by Percy Blenkcarne, a fellow New Zealander and one of the education staff, from a picture in the British Museum. The New Zealand Canterbury Battalion and some engineers laid out the design with tape and cut away the gorse and turfs to produce the Kiwi. During the 2nd World War the Kiwi was covered with earth but it was later restored and is now kept in good repair by 249 Signals Squadron.
